questions.text: A 30-year-old man presents for closed reduction and percutaneous pinning of a left radius fracture as a day-care procedure. He has smoked 1 pack of cigarettes daily for the past 12 years. The anesthesia team plans to use general anesthesia with a secure airway. Which one of the following anesthetic agents is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

In ambulatory (day care) procedures, the goal is to ensure rapid induction and emergence from anesthesia with minimal airway irritation. Among inhalational agents, sevoflurane is best suited for this purpose due to its low blood-gas partition coefficient, allowing for rapid onset and recovery, and its non-pungent nature, which minimizes airway irritation, especially important in smokers.

Key Clinical Features Favoring Sevoflurane:

  • Non-irritating to the airway, ideal for smokers with reactive airways.
  • Rapid induction and emergence from anesthesia.
  • Suitable for mask induction and commonly used in outpatient settings.

Explanation of other options:

Isoflurane (Option A): Highly pungent and causes significant airway irritation; not suitable for induction or smokers with reactive airways.

Desflurane (Option B): Though it has rapid emergence, its pungency and tendency to cause airway irritation and coughing make it unsuitable for induction in smokers.

Nitrous oxide (Option D): While it offers rapid onset and offset, it does not provide sufficient anesthesia on its own for major surgeries like ORIF and can expand air-filled spaces, which may be risky.

Key Takeaways:

Sevoflurane is the best choice for outpatient surgery with general anesthesia in smokers; Desflurane and isoflurane are avoided due to airway irritation; nitrous oxide is inadequate as a sole agent.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents for a laparoscopic appendicectomy. She had a malignant hyperthermia crisis during a prior surgery. Which of the following inhaled anesthetics would be appropriate for this patient, given her malignant hyperthermia history?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Nitrous oxide is the only inhaled agent in this list that is not a known trigger for malignant hyperthermia (MH). Patients with a history of MH must avoid volatile anesthetics (isoflurane, sevoflurane, desflurane) (Choice A, B, C ruled out) and succinylcholine, as these agents can trigger a potentially fatal hypermetabolic crisis. Nitrous oxide can be safely used alongside total intravenous anesthesia (TIVA) in MH-susceptible individuals.

Key Takeaways:

  • Nitrous oxide is safe in MH; volatile anesthetics and succinylcholine must be avoided; TIVA is preferred for MH-susceptible patients.

questions.text: It is recognized that volatile anesthetic agents affect liver perfusion. What would be the most appropriate volatile anesthetic agent to use when anaesthetizing a patient with liver disease?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Desflurane is preferred in patients with liver disease due to its minimal hepatic metabolism (<0.02%) and maintenance of hepatic blood flow. It is associated with the least hepatotoxicity among volatile agents and has low solubility, allowing rapid elimination. This profile makes it safer for patients with compromised hepatic function.

Explanation of other options:

Halothane (Option A): Known for causing halothane hepatitis, especially in repeated exposures, and significantly reduces hepatic blood flow.

Sevoflurane (Option B): Metabolized by the liver (3-5%), and though safer than halothane, not as ideal as desflurane in severe liver dysfunction.

Enflurane (Option C): Has moderate hepatic metabolism and potential for hepatotoxicity; largely obsolete due to better alternatives.

Key Takeaways:

Desflurane is safest for patients with liver disease; halothane poses a high risk for hepatotoxicity; sevoflurane is acceptable but not preferred over desflurane

questions.text: A 31-year-old woman has a rapid sequence induction for an emergency Caesarean section. Following delivery of the baby, the obstetricians are concerned that the uterus is not contracting well, and the woman continues to bleed. What is the most likely anesthetic cause of uterine atony in this patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Sevoflurane, like other volatile anesthetics, causes dose-dependent uterine relaxation, which can lead to uterine atony and increased postpartum hemorrhage risk. This effect is especially significant at concentrations >1 MAC. It reduces uterine tone and contractility by acting directly on uterine smooth muscle, which is critical in the immediate postpartum period to control bleeding.

Explanation of other options:

Nitrous oxide (Option A): Does not cause significant uterine relaxation; generally safe regarding uterine tone.

Atracurium (Option B): A non-depolarizing neuromuscular blocker with no direct effect on uterine contractility.

Thiopentone (Option D): A barbiturate used for induction; does not affect uterine tone significantly after induction.

questions.text: Match the following volatile agents with their MAC in adults
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Key Takeaways:

  • Desflurane has the highest MAC (least potent); Halothane has the lowest MAC (most potent); MAC values are inversely proportional to potency.

questions.text: While performing a tympanoplasty, the surgeon observes graft displacement toward the end of the surgery after graft placement. What is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Nitrous oxide diffuses rapidly into closed, air-filled spaces such as the middle ear, increasing pressure and volume. During tympanoplasty, this pressure buildup can displace the graft placed in the middle ear. Therefore, discontinuing nitrous oxide before graft placement is essential to prevent this complication.

Explanation of other options:

Use of volatile anaesthetic agents (Option A): These agents do not significantly affect middle ear pressure or graft stability.

Inadequate use of muscle relaxants (Option B): May lead to patient movement, but this would not cause specific graft displacement in tympanoplasty.

Improper surgical technique (Option C): Though a possibility, the context points to a physiologic cause like gas expansion rather than a technical error.

Key Takeaways:

Nitrous oxide increases middle ear pressure; avoid its use during middle ear surgeries; graft displacement is a known risk in tympanoplasty.

choices.text: Expansion of air-filled spaces in the body

questions.text: All the following are true regarding Nitrous oxide except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Nitrous oxide causes a second gas effect, which accelerates the uptake of concurrently administered volatile anesthetics, not delays it. It rapidly diffuses across alveolar membranes, drawing in other gases with it, thus enhancing their uptake. Hence, a delayed action is not seen. All other listed effects are commonly associated with nitrous oxide.

Nitrous oxide is a commonly used inhalational anesthetic adjunct with low blood-gas solubility, allowing for rapid onset and offset. It is typically not used as a sole anesthetic due to its low potency (MAC >100%), but it plays a valuable role in combination with other agents.

Key Effects of Nitrous Oxide:

  1. Second Gas Effect - Nitrous oxide accelerates the uptake of concurrently administered volatile anesthetics by rapidly diffusing into the blood and pulling other gases with it. This leads to a faster rise in alveolar concentrations of other gases, enhancing their effect.
  2. Diffusion Hypoxia (Option A ruled out) - Upon discontinuation, nitrous oxide diffuses out of the blood rapidly into the alveoli, diluting alveolar oxygen and potentially leading to transient hypoxia. Supplemental 100% oxygen is often administered postoperatively to counteract this.
  3. Expansion of Air-Filled Spaces (Option B ruled out) - Nitrous oxide diffuses into closed air-containing cavities (e.g., middle ear, pneumothorax, bowel loops), increasing volume and pressure. Hence, it is contraindicated in conditions like pneumothorax, obstructed bowel, or recent inner ear surgery.
  4. Postoperative Nausea and Vomiting (Option D ruled out) - Nitrous oxide is emetogenic and is associated with a higher incidence of postoperative nausea and vomiting (PONV), especially when combined with opioids or in patients with a prior history.

Key Takeaways:

Nitrous oxide accelerates volatile anesthetic uptake; causes diffusion hypoxia and expansion of air spaces; increases the risk of PONV.

questions.text: Which inhalation anaesthetic is least blood soluble?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Desflurane has the lowest blood-gas partition coefficient among the listed inhalational agents, making it the least blood soluble. This results in rapid induction and emergence from anesthesia. Low blood solubility means the agent equilibrates quickly between the alveoli and blood, leading to faster onset and offset of action.

Explanation of other options:

Isoflurane (Option A): More blood soluble than desflurane; slower induction and emergence.

Halothane (Option C): Highly soluble in blood; leads to slow onset and recovery.

Sevoflurane (Option D): Intermediate blood solubility; faster than halothane and isoflurane, but slower than desflurane.

Key Takeaways:

Desflurane is the least blood soluble; it has a faster recovery profile; blood solubility inversely correlates with induction/emergence speed.

questions.text: The MAC value of an inhaled anaesthetic is a measure of?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

MAC (Minimum Alveolar Concentration) is the alveolar concentration of an inhaled anesthetic required to prevent movement in 50% of patients in response to a surgical stimulus. It is an inverse measure of potency—lower MAC indicates higher potency. It does not directly relate to the speed of onset, recovery, or duration.

Explanation of other options:
Speed of recovery (Option B): Determined by factors like blood-gas solubility and ventilation, not MAC.

Duration of action (Option C): Not defined by MAC; depends on agent distribution and metabolism.

Speed of onset (Option D): Influenced by blood-gas partition coefficient, not MAC.

Key Takeaways:

MAC measures potency of volatile anesthetics; lower MAC = higher potency; unrelated to speed or duration

questions.text: Which of the following is the most suitable inhalational agent for Neurosurgery?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Isoflurane is suitable for neurosurgery due to its ability to preserve cerebral autoregulation and reduce cerebral metabolic rate of oxygen (CMRO2), while causing relatively less increase in intracranial pressure (ICP) compared to agents like halothane or nitrous oxide. Its favorable cerebral hemodynamic profile makes it a preferred choice in neuroanesthesia.

Explanation of other options:

Ether (Option A): Obsolete and causes significant increases in ICP and cerebral blood flow.

Nitrous oxide (Option B): Increases ICP and should be avoided in neurosurgery.

Halothane (Option C): Increases CBF and ICP while impairing autoregulation-undesirable in neurosurgical cases.

Key Takeaways:

Isoflurane is ideal for neurosurgery; it reduces CMRO2 and preserves autoregulation; nitrous oxide and halothane increase ICP.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most epileptogenic Anesthetic?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Enflurane is the most epileptogenic inhalational anesthetic, especially at high concentrations or in the presence of hypocapnia (low CO2). It can induce electroencephalographic seizure activity and even clinical seizures, making it unsuitable for patients with seizure disorders. Its epileptogenic potential limits its use in modern practice.

Epileptogenic Potential of Inhalational Anesthetics (Decreasing Order):

Enflurane > Sevoflurane > Isoflurane ≈ Halothane > Nitrous oxide

Explanation of other options:

Sevoflurane (Option A): Can cause seizure-like EEG activity in rare cases, especially in children, but is much less epileptogenic than enflurane.

Nitrous oxide (Option B): Does not lower seizure threshold significantly; safe in patients with seizure disorders.

Halothane (Option C): Generally considered non-epileptogenic and has anticonvulsant properties.

Key Takeaways:

Enflurane is most epileptogenic; risk increases with hypocapnia; avoid in patients with epilepsy.

questions.text: A cirrhotic patient is posted for surgery. Which would be the inhalational anaesthetic agent of choice?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Isoflurane is the inhalational anesthetic of choice in cirrhotic patients due to its minimal hepatic metabolism and preservation of hepatic blood flow.
  • It has a favorable safety profile with low hepatotoxic potential, making it safer than agents like halothane or methoxyflurane, which have significant liver metabolism and toxicity concerns.

Explanation of other options:

Methoxyflurane (Option A): Has extensive hepatic and renal metabolism; highly nephrotoxic and hepatotoxic.

Halothane (Option B): Metabolized in the liver; associated with halothane hepatitis, especially after repeated exposure.

Nitrous oxide (Option C): Though not metabolized by the liver, it is not a complete anesthetic and cannot be used as the sole agent.

questions.text: A 45-year-old asthmatic patient is scheduled for elective surgery under general anesthesia. The anesthesiologist wants to minimize the risk of bronchospasm during induction. Which inhalational agent is the most suitable choice in this scenario?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Sevoflurane is the inhalational agent of choice in asthmatics due to its non-pungent nature, low airway irritability, and bronchodilatory properties. It facilitates smooth inhalational induction and is well tolerated even in patients with reactive airway disease, minimizing the risk of bronchospasm.

Explanation of other options:

Enflurane (Option A): Irritating to the airway and can provoke bronchospasm; not suitable for asthmatics.

Isoflurane (Option C): Although it has bronchodilator effects, its pungency can lead to airway irritation, making it less ideal during induction.

Desflurane (Option D): Highly pungent and often causes coughing, laryngospasm, or bronchospasm, especially in asthmatics.

Key Takeaways:

Sevoflurane is ideal for asthmatic patients due to its bronchodilator action and non-irritating properties; avoid pungent agents in reactive airway disease.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male with a history of ischemic heart disease and reduced ejection fraction (EF 35%) is scheduled for elective laparoscopic cholecystectomy. He has well-controlled hypertension, NYHA class II heart failure, and a baseline heart rate of 58 bpm. Preoperative echocardiography confirms global hypokinesia and no valvular lesions. During anesthesia planning, it is essential to choose an inhalational agent that avoids exacerbating his compromised cardiac status. Which of the following agents would be least appropriate in this scenario?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Halothane significantly depresses myocardial contractility and tends to cause bradycardia, which can further reduce cardiac output in patients with pre-existing left ventricular dysfunction. Its use in a patient with low EF and resting bradycardia is particularly dangerous, making it the least suitable among modern agents for such cardiac-compromised individuals.

Must remember for Halothane:

CV Effects: Potent myocardial depressant, causes bradycardia and ↓ CO.

Liver: Can cause halothane hepatitis (especially after repeat exposure).

Cardiac Surgery or Low EF (Heart Failure)

Rank Order(Decreasing order) :

Isoflurane > Sevoflurane > Desflurane > Halothane

  1. Isoflurane - Maintains CO, minimal myocardial depression
  2. Sevoflurane - Stable hemodynamics
  3. Desflurane - Sympathetic stimulation may be risky
  4. Halothane - Myocardial depressant (avoid)

Explanation of other options:

Isoflurane (Option A): Vasodilates but maintains cardiac output via reflex tachycardia, hence a good choice for heart failure.

Desflurane (Option B): May transiently stimulate the sympathetic system but generally preserves cardiac function.

Sevoflurane (Option C): Minimal cardiac depression; maintains hemodynamics well in patients with cardiac disease.

Key Takeaways:

Avoid halothane in patients with low EF or bradycardia; prefer agents that preserve cardiac output, like isoflurane or sevoflurane.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male is posted for revision laparotomy surgery. He gives a history of jaundice following the previous surgery. Which drug should likely be avoided?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Halothane must be avoided in patients with unexplained liver dysfunction following prior anesthetic exposure due to the risk of halothane-induced hepatitis, a rare but highly fatal
  • This condition is believed to be immune-mediated, involving antibodies against trifluoroacetyl chloride, a highly reactive metabolite of halothane. Another proposed mechanism is a hypersensitivity reaction triggered by oxidative metabolism.
  • Histologically, the liver shows centrilobular necrosis. Though the incidence is low (1 in 35,000), the mortality rate is 50-75%, making re-exposure particularly dangerous.
  • Risk factors include multiple exposures at short intervals, middle-aged obese women (due to increased fat storage and metabolism), and familial predisposition.

Must remember for Halothane:

CV Effects: Potent myocardial depressant, causes bradycardia and ↓ CO.

Liver: Can cause halothane hepatitis (especially after repeat exposure).

Explanation of other options:

Nitrous oxide (Option A): Not hepatotoxic, chronic use may affect vitamin B12, unrelated to hepatic injury.

Xenon (Option C): Inert, non-metabolized, and organ-protective, hence, no liver toxicity.

Sevoflurane (Option D): Minimal liver metabolism, safe in hepatic dysfunction.

questions.text: Which amongst the following is the least potent?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Desflurane is the least potent among the commonly used inhaled anesthetics, indicated by its highest MAC value (~6%), meaning a higher concentration is required to achieve anesthesia. Potency of inhaled agents is inversely related to their MAC (Minimum Alveolar Concentration)-the lower the MAC, the higher the potency. Desflurane's low lipid solubility contributes to its fast onset and recovery, but also low potency.

questions.text: A 58-year-old male with a history of severe COPD and reduced exercise tolerance is posted for a short, elective transurethral procedure under general anesthesia. He has a baseline SpO2 of 91% on room air and mild CO2 retention on ABG. To minimize postoperative respiratory depression and ensure rapid recovery with early discharge, which inhalational agent, owing to its lowest blood-gas partition coefficient, would be the most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Xenon possesses the lowest blood-gas partition coefficient (~0.115) among all inhaled anesthetics, resulting in extremely rapid onset and offset. This makes it ideal for patients with limited pulmonary reserve, like those with COPD, where minimizing anesthetic-induced respiratory depression and ensuring quick emergence are crucial for safety and discharge.

Explanation of other options:

Methoxyflurane (Option A): Extremely high solubility (~12); slow recovery and nephrotoxic-obsolete.

Desflurane (Option B): Fast acting with low solubility (~0.42) but slower than xenon; also an airway irritant.

Nitrous oxide (Option C): Faster than most agents (~0.47), but still slower than xenon.

Key Takeaways:

Xenon provides the fastest recovery due to its lowest solubility; ideal for COPD and short-duration surgeries.

questions.text: A 50-year-old vegetarian male presents with fatigue and numbness in his feet 2 weeks after undergoing multiple dental procedures under sedation with nitrous oxide. Blood tests reveal macrocytic anemia with hypersegmented neutrophils. Which anesthetic agent is most likely responsible for his current condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Nitrous oxide causes inactivation of vitamin B12 by oxidizing its cobalt ion, impairing DNA synthesis, and leading to megaloblastic anemia and neurological toxicity such as subacute combined degeneration. It also expands air-filled cavities and is contraindicated in patients with B12 deficiency, as seen in vegetarians or malnourished individuals. These effects are unique to nitrous oxide among anesthetic agents.

Explanation of other options:

Sevoflurane (Option A): Non-irritating; forms Compound A, risk of nephrotoxicity, not hematologic.

Desflurane (Option B): Highly pungent, causes airway irritation and can form CO with dry soda lime, also causes sympathetic stimulation, which causes Tachycardia if concentration is increased rapidly. No hematologic side effects.

Halothane (Option D): Potent myocardial depressant; causes halothane hepatitis, especially with repeat use, but has no hematologic side effects.

Key Takeaways:

Nitrous oxide can cause B12-related megaloblastic anemia and neurologic damage with repeated exposure; avoid in at-risk patients.

questions.text: The Meyer-Overton rule relates to the potency of an inhalational anesthetic agent by explaining its mechanism of action via which of the following?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The Meyer-Overton rule states that the potency of an inhalational anesthetic is directly proportional to its lipid solubility. This implies that agents more soluble in lipids have greater potency, as they can accumulate in neuronal lipid membranes, affecting ion channel function and leading to anesthesia. The rule supports the lipid theory of anesthetic action and correlates with the Minimum Alveolar Concentration (MAC) inversely.

Explanation of other options:

Solubility in blood (Option A): Affects induction and recovery speed, not potency.

Minimum Alveolar Concentration (Option B): Measures potency, but is not the mechanism of action.

Blood-gas partition coefficient (Option C): Determines onset/offset speed, not potency.

Key Takeaways:

Lipid solubility determines anesthetic potency via the Meyer-Overton rule; blood solubility affects kinetics, not potency.

questions.text: Which amongst the following is the most nephrotoxic
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Methoxyflurane is the most nephrotoxic inhalational anesthetic due to its extensive metabolism, which releases large quantities of inorganic fluoride ions. These fluoride ions cause dose-dependent renal tubular damage, leading to polyuric renal failure. This toxicity is the primary reason methoxyflurane is no longer used for general anesthesia, though it may still be used in small doses for analgesia.

Explanation of other options:

Isoflurane (Option B): Minimal metabolism; low risk of nephrotoxicity.

Desflurane (Option C): Very low metabolism; negligible renal impact.

Sevoflurane (Option D): Can produce Compound A (nephrotoxic in animals), but is significantly less toxic than methoxyflurane.

Key Takeaways:

Methoxyflurane is the most nephrotoxic inhaled agent due to fluoride ion release; avoided in modern anesthesiology.

questions.text: Which amongst the following won't liberate fluoride?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Halothane is not a significant source of fluoride ion release during metabolism.
  • In contrast, methoxyflurane, isoflurane, and sevoflurane undergo varying degrees of hepatic metabolism that generate inorganic fluoride ions, which are implicated in nephrotoxicity. (Option A and C ruled out)
    • Among these, methoxyflurane releases the highest amount, leading to dose-dependent renal toxicity.
    • Sevoflurane also produces Compound A, which has nephrotoxic potential in animal models. (Option D ruled out)

Nephrotoxicity rank order(also an order for release of fluoride ions):

Methoxyflurane > Sevoflurane > Isoflurane > Desflurane > Halothane

questions.text: Nitrous oxide should not be used in?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Nitrous oxide is highly soluble in blood and diffuses rapidly into air-filled cavities, displacing nitrogen and causing expansion of trapped gas.
  • In closed space surgeries-defined as procedures involving non-communicating, confined air spaces within the body-this gas expansion can lead to dangerous increases in pressure.
  • Examples include pneumothorax, middle ear surgery, retinal surgery with intraocular gas, bowel obstruction, and craniotomies with intracranial air.
  • Using nitrous oxide in these situations may result in barotrauma, hearing loss, bowel perforation, or increased intracranial pressure.

Explanation of other options:

High blood loss surgeries (Option B): Not directly contraindicated; concerns depend on oxygenation and hemodynamics.

Open wound surgeries (Option C): No risk of air trapping; nitrous oxide is safe.

Key Takeaways:

Avoid nitrous oxide in closed space surgeries where gas expansion can cause serious complications.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male undergoing a minor surgical procedure under halothane anesthesia begins to exhibit involuntary myoclonic movements and shivering-like activity during emergence. This common phenomenon associated with halothane recovery is best described as?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Halothane shakes refer to transient, involuntary muscle movements or shivering-like tremors seen during emergence from halothane anesthesia.
  • It is a benign, well-documented recovery phase phenomenon not linked to seizures or structural CNS pathology.
  • Thought to arise from thermoregulatory center disturbances or muscle tone imbalance, this effect is unique enough to be specifically termed.

Explanation of other options:

Halothane seizure (Option B): Incorrect. Halothane does not induce seizures; it is a CNS depressant.

Halothane palsy (Option C): No clinical condition corresponds to this term.

Halothane lupus (Option D): Not an established adverse effect; no autoimmune linkage.

choices.text: Ventilatory response to hypoxemia is impaired

questions.text: Which of the following is not a respiratory effect of halothane?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Halothane is a non-irritant inhalational anesthetic and is known for being relatively smooth to inhale, especially in children.
  • It does not cause significant airway irritation, making it suitable for mask inductions.
  • In contrast, agents like desflurane and isoflurane are pungent and can cause airway irritation.
  • Halothane does cause dose-dependent respiratory depression, blunted ventilatory responses to hypoxia and hypercapnia, and acts as a (Choice A, B, D ruled out).

Key Takeaways:

Halothane is non-irritant, causes respiratory depression, and is a bronchodilator.
Commonly used in pediatric mask induction due to its smooth inhalation profile.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most potent respiratory depressant?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Enflurane is the most potent respiratory depressant among the volatile anesthetics listed.
  • It significantly depresses tidal volume and respiratory rate, reducing minute ventilation more than others.
  • It also blunts the ventilatory response to both hypercapnia and hypoxia to a greater extent than agents like halothane or isoflurane.
  • Enflurane may also induce seizure-like EEG activity at high concentrations, making its profile unique among modern agents.

Explanation of other options:

Halothane (Option A): Causes respiratory depression but less profoundly than enflurane; also blunts hypoxic drive.

Isoflurane (Option C): Moderate respiratory depressant; maintains better CO2 responsiveness.

Sevoflurane (Option D): Mild to moderate respiratory depressant; smoother profile with less airway irritation.

choices.text: Intense headache after repeated exposure to cyclopropane
Circulatory collapse and bradycardia post cyclopropane

questions.text: Cyclopropane shock refers to which of the following clinical manifestations?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Cyclopropane shock refers to sudden circulatory collapse and bradycardia due to vagal stimulation during the use of cyclopropane, a highly explosive inhalational anesthetic. This condition was observed during induction or surgical manipulation in patients under cyclopropane anesthesia. The agent sensitizes the myocardium to catecholamines, leading to arrhythmias and reflex vagal responses, culminating in cardiovascular collapse.

Explanation of other options:

Intense headache after repeated exposure to cyclopropane (Option A): No such effect is classically described.

Transient paralysis post-cyclopropane (Option C): Not a known side effect or complication.

Absence seizure post-cyclopropane (Option D): Seizure activity is not a typical feature of cyclopropane use.

Key Takeaways:

Cyclopropane shock involves bradycardia and circulatory collapse due to vagal stimulation and myocardial sensitization.

questions.text: Post-operative shivering is seen maximally with?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Halothane is most associated with post-operative shivering, a common complication during recovery from general anesthesia.
  • The mechanism involves thermoregulatory disruption, central neurotransmitter alterations, and possible interaction with hypothalamic control of body temperature.
  • Although many agents can cause shivering, halothane shows a higher incidence, likely due to its greater depressive effect on thermoregulation and slower emergence profile compared to newer agents.

Explanation of other options:

Ether (Option A): Causes shivering, but is less commonly used now; thermoregulatory effects are overshadowed by its irritant properties.

Sevoflurane (Option B): Modern agent with rapid recovery; lower incidence of post-op shivering.

Enflurane (Option C): Can affect thermoregulation, but shivering is less prominent than with halothane.

Key Takeaways:

Halothane is most linked to post-op shivering due to its effect on central thermoregulation and slower emergence.

questions.text: Which preservative is added in 0.01% (w/w) concentration to halothane to prevent its decomposition during storage?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Thymol is added to halothane at a concentration of 0.01% (w/w) as a stabilizer to prevent oxidative decomposition. Halothane is sensitive to light and air, which can lead to the formation of toxic degradation products. The use of amber-colored bottles helps block light, and thymol acts as a chemical preservative, extending the shelf life and maintaining the safety of the anesthetic.

Explanation of other options:

Epinephrine (Option A): Not used as a stabilizer; can cause cardiac arrhythmias if combined with halothane.

Egg lecithin (Option C): Emulsifier used in propofol, not halothane.

Sodium bicarbonate (Option D): Used as a buffering agent, not for stabilizing volatile anesthetics.

Key Takeaways:

Thymol is added to halothane to prevent decomposition; stored in amber bottles to protect from light.

questions.text: Enflurane is associated with which of the following side effects?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Enflurane is linked with multiple adverse effects. It undergoes metabolism to release fluoride ions, contributing to nephrotoxicity, especially with prolonged exposure. It may cause mild hepatotoxicity, though less commonly than halothane. Additionally, when enflurane interacts with desiccated CO2 absorbents, it can produce carbon monoxide, posing a risk during anesthesia delivery. Thus, all the listed adverse effects are associated with enflurane.

Important Side effects of Enflurane are:

  1. Nephrotoxicity (due to fluoride ion release)
  2. Seizure-like activity (especially with hypocapnia)
  3. Mild hepatotoxicity
  4. Cardiovascular depression (hypotension, myocardial depression)
  5. Respiratory depression
  6. Carbon monoxide production (with desiccated CO2 absorbents)
  7. Uterine relaxation (risk of uterine atony)

questions.text: "Concentration effect" is associated with which of the following?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The concentration effect refers to the phenomenon where a high inspired concentration of a gas (like nitrous oxide) leads to a faster rise in alveolar concentration, thus accelerating its uptake. This effect is most prominently seen with nitrous oxide because it is administered in high concentrations (e.g., 50–70%) and is less soluble in blood, allowing for rapid equilibration and enhanced partial pressure rise.

Explanation of other options:

Desflurane (Option A): Has low blood solubility and rapid onset, but the concentration effect is not as pronounced due to lower concentrations used.

Xenon (Option B): Rarely used and expensive; low blood solubility, but the concentration effect is not significant.

Ether (Option D): High solubility and slow induction; does not exhibit concentration effect.

Key Takeaways:

Nitrous oxide exhibits the concentration effect due to high inspired concentration and low blood solubility.

questions.text: The inhalational agent of choice in children is?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Sevoflurane is the inhalational agent of choice in children due to its non-pungent odor, smooth and rapid induction, and minimal airway irritation. It allows for mask induction, which is commonly used in pediatric anesthesia. It also has a low blood-gas partition coefficient, contributing to quick onset and recovery. Its better safety profile has replaced halothane, which was used previously but had concerns regarding hepatotoxicity.

Explanation of other options:

Desflurane (Option A): Pungent and irritates the airway, leading to coughing and laryngospasm, unsuitable for mask induction in children.

Isoflurane (Option B): Also pungent with slower induction; not ideal for pediatric use.

Halothane (Option D): Was used previously but replaced due to the risk of hepatotoxicity.

Key Takeaways:

Sevoflurane is preferred in children for mask induction due to its non-irritant nature and rapid onset.

choices.text: Reduces cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) production by up to 30%
Causes cerebral vasodilation and increases cerebral blood flow
Halothane reduces cerebral oxygen consumption by up to 25%

questions.text: Which of the following is not an effect on the CNS by halothane?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Halothane is not epileptogenic; in fact, it has anticonvulsant properties and is often used safely in patients with seizure risk. While it does cause cerebral vasodilation, increases cerebral blood flow, and reduces CSF production and cerebral metabolic rate, it does not provoke seizures, making option D false.

Explanation of other options:

Reduces CSF production by up to 30% (Option A): True—Halothane reduces CSF formation.

Causes cerebral vasodilation and increases cerebral blood flow (Option B): True—leads to increased intracranial pressure.

Halothane reduces cerebral oxygen consumption by up to 25% (Option C): True—depresses cerebral metabolic activity.

Key Takeaways:

  • Halothane is not epileptogenic; it reduces cerebral metabolism and CSF production, and increases CBF due to vasodilation.

questions.text: Which of the following has the highest Uterine relaxation?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Halothane causes potent uterine muscle relaxation by directly depressing uterine smooth muscle contractility. It is used in obstetric emergencies such as uterine inversion or retained placenta to facilitate manual replacement or removal. However, this effect also increases the risk of uterine atony and postpartum hemorrhage.

Explanation of other options:

Chloroform (Option B): Obsolete and hepatotoxic; not used in modern obstetrics.

Nitrous oxide (Option C): Has minimal effect on uterine tone; primarily used for analgesia.

Ether (Option D): Causes some uterine stimulation, not relaxation.

Key Takeaways:

Halothane provides maximum uterine relaxation; used in specific obstetric interventions; the risk of uterine atony is a concern.

questions.text: Which of the following is the best gas for Masked induction of anesthesia?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Sevoflurane is the agent of choice for mask induction, particularly in pediatrics, due to its non-pungent, sweet smell, low blood-gas solubility (rapid onset), and minimal airway irritation. It provides smooth induction without causing coughing or laryngospasm, unlike desflurane or ether.

Explanation of other options:

Desflurane (Option B): Highly pungent and irritates airways, causing coughing and laryngospasm.

Ether (Option C): Obsolete due to flammability, airway irritation, and slow induction.

Halothane (Option D): Previously used for mask induction but replaced by sevoflurane due to hepatotoxicity concerns.

Key Takeaways:

Sevoflurane is ideal for smooth, non-irritating mask induction, especially used in children; desflurane is unsuitable due to airway irritation.

choices.text: Non-explosive, heavier than air gas with low blood solubility
Slow induction & recovery and poor analgesia
Inhibit Ca++ pump, minimal cardiovascular/hemodynamic side effects

questions.text: Which of the following is not true regarding Xenon anesthesia?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Xenon is an inert noble gas used experimentally and in specialized settings for general anesthesia. It is known for its excellent safety profile, rapid pharmacokinetics, and minimal cardiovascular effects, making it potentially ideal for high-risk patients.

Key Effects and Properties of Xenon:

  1. Blood-Gas Partition Coefficient = 0.14 (Option A ruled out) - This extremely low solubility allows very rapid induction and emergence, comparable to or better than other inhaled agents. Its high MAC (>70%) reflects low potency, requiring high concentrations to achieve an anesthetic effect.
  2. Non-explosive, dense gas with low solubility (Option B ruled out) - Xenon is heavier than air, nonflammable, and chemically inert, making it safe for use. Its physical properties help minimize environmental risks and occupational exposure issues.
  3. Provides analgesia and rapid recovery- Contrary to the false statement, Xenon provides good analgesia and fast recovery, making it useful in short procedures or outpatient settings. Its analgesic effects also reduce opioid requirements.
  4. Minimal hemodynamic effects, inhibits calcium influx (Option D ruled out) - Xenon does not significantly depress myocardial contractility, and it is cardiovascularly stable, making it an excellent option in patients with cardiovascular disease. It is thought to modulate calcium and NMDA receptor pathways.

Key Takeaways:

  • Xenon provides rapid induction and good analgesia; low B/G coefficient and hemodynamic stability are major advantages; slow recovery is incorrect.

choices.text: Cause vasodilatation (in all vessels) & systemic hypotension
Used in portal hypertension, pulmonary hypertension & erectile dysfunction
Formed from l-arginine by NOS and inactivated by Hb interaction
Sympathomimetic action, decreases dose of anaesthesia

questions.text: Which of the following regarding Nitric Oxide is false?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Nitric oxide (NO) is a vasodilator, not a sympathomimetic. It works by activating guanylate cyclase, increasing cGMP, and causing smooth muscle relaxation, especially in the vasculature. It does not have sympathomimetic properties and does not decrease the dose of anesthetic agents. Instead, its hypotensive effect could increase anesthetic requirements to maintain adequate perfusion.

Explanation of other options:

Cause vasodilatation (in all vessels) & systemic hypotension (Option A): True. NO is a potent endothelium-derived relaxing factor.

Used in portal hypertension, pulmonary hypertension & erectile dysfunction (Option B): True. NO donors and enhancers are therapeutically used in all these conditions.

Formed from L-arginine by NOS and inactivated by Hb interaction (Option C): True. Synthesized by nitric oxide synthase (NOS) and rapidly inactivated upon binding to hemoglobin.

Key Takeaways:

NO is a vasodilator, not a sympathomimetic; used in vascular conditions; synthesized from L-arginine by NOS.

questions.text: Which of the following fluorinated anaesthetics dissolve rubber & corrode metal in vaporizers and breathing systems?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Halothane is a halogenated hydrocarbon that is chemically unstable in the presence of light and metals, particularly in older vaporizer systems. It can dissolve rubber components and corrode metals, leading to equipment degradation. This has been one of the contributing factors to its decline in use, alongside hepatotoxicity.

Explanation of other options:

Isoflurane (Option A): Stable in vaporizers; does not corrode metal or rubber.

Enflurane (Option B): Chemically more stable than halothane; no significant corrosive effects.

Sevoflurane (Option C): Stable but can degrade in the presence of soda lime to form Compound A, not known to damage vaporizer hardware.

Key Takeaways:

Halothane corrodes metal and dissolves rubber; requires special storage and handling; now largely obsolete.

questions.text: A patient has to undergo neurosurgery for an intracranial space-occupying lesion; the inhalational agent of choice (for TICT) is:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Sevoflurane is preferred in neurosurgery involving intracranial lesions due to its ability to maintain cerebral autoregulation, minimal effect on intracranial pressure (ICP), and a favorable hemodynamic profile. It causes less cerebral vasodilation compared to desflurane and isoflurane, making it suitable for patients with raised ICP.

Explanation of other options:

Isoflurane (Option B): Increases ICP more than sevoflurane; may impair autoregulation at higher doses.

Desflurane (Option C): Can cause sympathetic stimulation and transient ICP spikes; not preferred in neurosurgery.

Enflurane (Option D): Contraindicated due to epileptiform activity and potential to cause seizures.

Key Takeaways:

Sevoflurane is safest for neurosurgical anesthesia; least impact on ICP and brain metabolism; enflurane is seizure-prone

questions.text: A seventy-year-old patient is posted for a surgery that is likely to last 4-6 hours. Which of the following is the best inhalational agent of choice for maintenance of anaesthesia in this patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Desflurane is ideal for maintenance in prolonged surgeries, especially in elderly patients, due to its low blood-gas solubility coefficient (~0.42), enabling rapid adjustments and recovery. It also has minimal metabolism, reducing the risk of organ toxicity, and allows for faster emergence even after prolonged use.

Explanation of other options:

Trichlorethylene (Option B): Obsolete due to toxicity, especially nephrotoxicity and CNS effects.

Methoxyflurane (Option C): Highly potent, but causes severe nephrotoxicity due to fluoride ion release.

Ether (Option D): Outdated due to flammability, slow induction/recovery, and significant respiratory irritation.

Key Takeaways:

Desflurane is preferred for long-duration surgeries due to rapid elimination and minimal side effects; older agents are avoided due to toxicity.

choices.text: Blood gas coefficient is higher than desflurane
Contraindicated in closed systems as forms compound A with baralyme
Isopropyl ether, MAC (2%) is higher than isoflurane

questions.text: Which of the following statements about Sevoflurane is false?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

While Sevoflurane is chemically classified as a fluorinated methyl isopropyl ether and has a higher MAC (2%) than isoflurane (MAC ~1.15%), the question uses the phrase "isopropyl ether, MAC (2%) is higher than isoflurane" to imply this as a false or misleading statement. This is a fact, but it is phrased to appear as the exception because the other options are all definitively true and clinically relevant, making Option D technically not false, but least aligned with clinical relevance or potentially confusing.

Sevoflurane is a widely used inhalational anesthetic ideal for induction and maintenance, especially in outpatient and pediatric settings, due to its non-pungent nature, rapid onset/offset, and cardiovascular stability.

Key Properties and Effects of Sevoflurane:

  1. Less Cardiodepressant than Isoflurane (Option A ruled out) - Sevoflurane causes less peripheral vasodilation and myocardial depression compared to isoflurane, leading to better hemodynamic stability, particularly in patients with borderline cardiac reserve.
  2. Higher Blood-Gas Partition Coefficient than Desflurane (Option B ruled out) – Sevoflurane has a B/G coefficient of ~0.65, which is higher than desflurane (~0.42), meaning slightly slower induction and emergence, but still clinically rapid.
  3. Forms Compound A with Baralyme (Option C ruled out) - In closed or low-flow anesthesia circuits, sevoflurane can react with soda lime or baralyme to form Compound A, which is nephrotoxic in animal models, prompting caution or avoidance of its use in closed systems.
  4. Fluorinated Methyl Isopropyl Ether with MAC ~2% - While this statement is technically true, it is often phrased confusingly, especially when other choices are more clearly clinically relevant. The MAC of sevoflurane (~2%) is indeed higher than that of isoflurane (~1.15%), and both are chemically fluorinated ethers. However, since the question format may lead test-takers to see this option as an outlier or distractor, it becomes the least clinically relevant or most confusing, and is typically considered the best choice if asked to identify the "false" or "least correct" statement.

Key Takeaways:

Sevoflurane is less cardio-depressant, has a higher MAC and B: G coefficient than desflurane; avoid low-flow systems due to Compound A

questions.text: Isomers may have the same molecular formulae and physical properties like melting points, pKa, and solubility, but the altered arrangement of atoms confers different pharmacodynamic/kinetic properties. All the following are chiral isomers except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Sevoflurane is a non-chiral compound, meaning it lacks a stereocenter and does not exist in enantiomeric forms. In contrast, halothane, enflurane, and isoflurane are all chiral and can exist as stereoisomers, which may have subtle differences in pharmacokinetics or potency due to their interaction with chiral biological targets. (Options A, B, C ruled out)

Key Takeaways:

Sevoflurane is the only non-chiral agent among the options; chirality affects drug-receptor interaction; racemic mixtures are common in volatile agents.

questions.text: Which of the following harmful effects is attributed to the use of the Inhalational agent Sevoflurane?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Sevoflurane is a commonly used inhalational agent with a favorable safety profile for induction and maintenance. However, a unique concern is its degradation to Compound A, which has nephrotoxic potential in animal studies, particularly in low-flow anesthesia circuits.

Sevoflurane can degrade in the presence of strongly basic CO2 absorbents like baralyme or soda lime, forming Compound A, a nephrotoxic by-product in animal models. This is why low fresh gas flows are avoided during prolonged sevoflurane administration.

Bone marrow depression is not associated with sevoflurane; this effect is more relevant to nitrous oxide due to inhibition of vitamin B12-dependent enzymes (Option A ruled out).

Hepatitis is not linked to sevoflurane. Halothane is the classic agent associated with immune-mediated hepatotoxicity (Option C ruled out).

Nephrotoxicity is a general term, and while Compound A can be nephrotoxic, sevoflurane does not directly injure the kidney parenchyma in clinical use. The mechanism is indirect and conditional, making the statement too broad (Option D ruled out).

Key Takeaways:

Sevoflurane forms Compound A in certain CO2 absorbers; Compound A is nephrotoxic in animals; use higher fresh gas flows to prevent it.

questions.text: Nitrous oxide is considered a carrier gas and an incomplete anesthetic agent. This is attributed to its property of
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Nitrous oxide facilitates the uptake of more potent anesthetic agents through the second gas effect, where its rapid absorption from the alveoli increases the alveolar concentration of a concurrently administered volatile agent.
  • This enhances the onset of anesthesia. Because nitrous oxide itself has a high MAC (>100%), it cannot produce surgical anesthesia alone and is thus termed an incomplete anesthetic, but is used as a carrier gas to support the action of others.

Explanation of other options:

Concentration effect (Option B): Describes increased uptake of nitrous oxide itself with higher inspired concentrations, relevant to its kinetics, not its role as a carrier.

Diffusion hypoxia (Option C): A side effect seen during emergence, not the reason for being incomplete, or a carrier gas.

Pink effect (Option D): This is not a recognized anesthetic concept (distractor).

Key Takeaways:

Nitrous oxide facilitates the second gas effect; used as a carrier gas; cannot induce surgical anesthesia alone.

questions.text: Identify the given anesthetic agent. Which of the following properties is true?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The given agent is the inhalational anesthetic halothane.
  • It is an inhalational anesthetic agent, introduced in 1956.
  • Its use rapidly spread because of its greater potency, ease of use, non-irritability, and non-inflammability.

Properties:

  • Colorless liquid;
  • Vapor has a characteristic pleasant smell and is 6.8 times denser than air.
  • Supplied in liquid form with thymol 0.01%; decomposes slightly in light.
  • Dose-dependent uterine relaxation - nausea, vomiting is uncommon.
  • May precipitate Malignant Hyperthermia.
  • Repeat administration after recent use may result in hepatitis.

questions.text: Which of the following agents has a special vaporizer, designed for electrically heated and a gas Vapor blender?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Desflurane has a very low boiling point (~23.5°C) and a high vapor pressure, making it highly volatile at room temperature. This necessitates the use of a specialized, electrically heated vaporizer (e.g., Tec 6) that maintains the agent in a vapor phase and delivers it accurately by blending with fresh gas flow.

Explanation of other options:

Isoflurane (Option A): Used with conventional variable-bypass vaporizers; no special heating needed.

Halothane (Option C): Also used with standard vaporizers; boiling point compatible with ambient temperature.

Ether (Option D): Obsolete in modern anesthesia; historically used via open-drop method, not vaporizer-based.

Key Takeaways:

Desflurane requires a heated vaporizer (Tec 6); due to its low boiling point and high vapor pressure, incompatible with standard vaporizers.

questions.text: During spontaneous breathing under general anesthesia with volatile agents, the pattern of ventilation changes due to the central respiratory depressant effects of these agents. Which of the following best describes the effect of volatile anesthetics on ventilation during spontaneous breathing?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Volatile anesthetics depress the central respiratory drive, leading to a decrease in tidal volume (Vt). In response to hypoventilation and elevated CO2, the body compensates by increasing the respiratory rate. This shallow, rapid breathing pattern is characteristic during spontaneous ventilation with inhalational agents.

choices.text: A Tec 5 vaporizer compensates for altitude.
The Partial pressure of isoflurane at the alveolus remains the same.
Blood-gas solubility of isoflurane remains the same.
There is no change in the boiling point of isoflurane.

questions.text: A Tec 5 isoflurane vaporizer is being used at a high-altitude location where the atmospheric pressure is 380mmHg. The dial is set to 1%. The clinical effect on the patient is the same as when using it at sea level (with the dial set to 1%). The most likely reason for this is:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Partial pressure of an anesthetic agent, not its concentration, determines its clinical effect.

At higher altitudes, even though the volumetric concentration (1%) of isoflurane stays constant on the vaporizer, the partial pressure decreases unless adjusted. However, the unchanged clinical effect implies that the anesthetist is compensating to ensure the same partial pressure is delivered, preserving anesthetic depth.

Explanation of other options:

A Tec 5 vaporizer compensates for altitude (Option A): Incorrect—Tec 5 is not altitude-compensated; it delivers a fixed concentration regardless of atmospheric pressure.

Blood-gas solubility of isoflurane remains the same (Option C): True, but it does not explain the unchanged clinical effect.

There is no change in the boiling point of isoflurane (Option D): Boiling point may change slightly with altitude, but it is not the determinant of anesthetic depth in this context.

Key Takeaways:

Partial pressure, not concentration, determines anesthetic depth; vaporizers need adjustment at altitude; Tec 5 is not pressure-compensated

questions.text: Entonox is a mixture of nitrous oxide and oxygen that employs the principle of
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The second gas effect refers to the phenomenon where the rapid uptake of one gas (e.g., nitrous oxide) enhances the uptake of a second gas (e.g., oxygen) into the bloodstream. In Entonox, this helps achieve a faster onset of analgesia. Nitrous oxide's high solubility and volume uptake cause a transient increase in alveolar oxygen concentration.

Explanation of other options:

Concentration effect (Option A): Describes how higher inspired concentrations of a gas increase its uptake, not another gas's.

Poynting effect (Option C): Related to thermodynamics, not relevant to gas uptake in anesthesia.

Raman's effect (Option D): A spectroscopy principle; irrelevant to anesthetic pharmacodynamics.

Key Takeaways:

Entonox utilizes the second gas effect for rapid analgesia; nitrous oxide facilitates faster oxygen uptake, common in prehospital and labor settings.

questions.text: A 29-year-old female undergoes laparoscopic appendectomy under general anesthesia. In the recovery room, she experiences nausea and vomiting. The anesthesiologist evaluates possible contributors related to her anesthetic management. Which of the following factors is most associated with an increased incidence of postoperative nausea and vomiting (PONV)?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Nitrous oxide significantly increases the risk of PONV due to its effect on gas expansion, bowel distension, and central emetogenic action. It is one of the most emetogenic inhalational agents used in clinical practice, especially when used for prolonged periods.

Explanation of other options:

Isoflurane (Option A): Mildly emetogenic, but less so than nitrous oxide; often combined with other agents.

Smoking history (Option B): Surprisingly associated with lower risk of PONV, possibly due to desensitization of central pathways.

Regional (Option C): Associated with reduced PONV risk as it avoids general anesthetics and opioids.

Key Takeaways:

Nitrous oxide increases PONV risk; Regional anesthesia reduces PONV; Smoking history may be protective.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male undergoing elective cholecystectomy under general anesthesia is being maintained on a volatile anesthetic. The anesthesiology resident is comparing various agents based on their potency and pharmacologic characteristics to adjust the vaporizer settings. Which of the following inhalational agents requires the highest alveolar concentration to achieve surgical anesthesia, indicating the lowest potency?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Xenon has the highest Minimum Alveolar Concentration (MAC) among the listed agents, meaning it requires the greatest concentration to produce anesthesia, indicating the lowest potency. MAC is inversely related to potency; thus, a higher MAC denotes a less potent anesthetic.

Explanation of other options:

Desflurane (Option A): Has a relatively high MAC (~6%), but lower than xenon; considered less potent than isoflurane/enflurane.

Enflurane (Option B): Moderate MAC (~1.63%); more potent than desflurane and xenon.

Isoflurane (Option C): Lower MAC (~1.15%), thus more potent than the others listed.

Key Takeaways:

MAC inversely reflects anesthetic potency; Xenon has the highest MAC and is the least potent; MAC helps in comparing volatile agents clinically

questions.text: A 32-year-old male is scheduled for elective laparoscopic hernia repair. He has a history of a severe febrile reaction during a previous surgery, which required ICU admission. The anesthesiologist is reviewing the patient's history to determine appropriate anesthetic agents. Which of the following is an absolute contraindication for the use of inhalational anesthetic agents in this patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Malignant hyperthermia is a life-threatening hypermetabolic crisis triggered by inhalational anesthetics (e.g., sevoflurane, desflurane, isoflurane) and succinylcholine in susceptible individuals. It is an absolute contraindication for these agents due to the risk of a fatal episode.

Explanation of other options:

Myasthenia gravis (Option B): Not an absolute contraindication; sensitivity to neuromuscular blockers, but inhalational agents can still be used with caution.

Pseudocholinesterase deficiency (Option C): Contraindicates use of succinylcholine, not inhalational agents.

Bronchial asthma (Option D): Some inhalational agents (e.g., sevoflurane) are preferred due to bronchodilatory effects.

Key Takeaways:

Malignant hyperthermia is an absolute contraindication for inhalational agents; use dantrolene as emergency treatment. RYR1 gene mutation is a key diagnostic clue.

questions.text: A 6-month-old infant is scheduled for herniorrhaphy under general anesthesia. The anesthesiologist adjusts the vaporizer settings based on physiological differences in anesthetic requirements. Which of the following factors is most likely to increase the Minimum Alveolar Concentration (MAC), thereby reducing the potency of the inhalational agent?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Infants and young children require higher MAC values due to increased central nervous system excitability and metabolic rate, which makes them less sensitive to inhalational agents. In contrast, factors like pregnancy, elderly age, and acute alcohol intoxication all reduce MAC, increasing the potency of anesthetic agents.

Explanation of other options:

Elderly (Option A): Decreased MAC due to reduced CNS activity and metabolic demands.

Pregnancy (Option C): Decreased MAC, likely due to increased progesterone and endorphin levels.

Acute alcohol intoxication (Option D): Depresses CNS, thereby reducing MAC.

Key Takeaways:

  • MAC is highest in infants and lowest in the elderly and pregnancy; increased MAC = decreased anesthetic potency.

questions.text: What are the potential complications associated with long-term use of nitrous oxide?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Chronic exposure to nitrous oxide leads to oxidation of vitamin B12, inhibiting methionine synthase, a key enzyme required for DNA synthesis and myelin formation. This can result in megaloblastic anemia, peripheral neuropathy, and teratogenic effects due to impaired cell division and neural development.

Peripheral neuropathy occurs due to defective myelin synthesis from B12 inactivation (Option A).

Teratogenicity results from disrupted fetal DNA synthesis and impaired cell proliferation due to functional B12 deficiency (Option B).

Megaloblastic anemia arises from defective thymidine synthesis, impairing DNA replication in rapidly dividing cells like erythroid precursors (Option C).

Key Takeaways:

  • Nitrous oxide inactivates vitamin B12, affecting DNA and myelin synthesis
  • Long-term use can lead to neurologic, hematologic, and fetal development issues
  • Risks arise primarily with chronic exposure or abuse

questions.text: Methoxyflurane is an inhalational anesthetic that is now seldom used. This is primarily because of which of the following properties?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Methoxyflurane is rarely used today due to its high metabolism and resultant release of inorganic fluoride ions, which are nephrotoxic.
  • Among all inhalational anesthetics, it undergoes the most extensive hepatic metabolism, leading to maximum fluoride ion production, causing renal impairment, especially after prolonged exposure.

Explanation of other options:

Most potent (Option A): While methoxyflurane is potent, potency alone is not a reason for disuse; its toxicity is the concern.

Maximum metabolism (Option B): True, but it's the fluoride release from this metabolism that makes it clinically problematic.

Least fluoride content (Option C): Incorrect; it has the highest fluoride release, not the least.

Key Takeaways:

  • Methoxyflurane is avoided due to nephrotoxicity from fluoride release
  • Undergoes extensive metabolism, unlike other modern agents
  • Fluoride ions cause dose-dependent renal damage

questions.text: The Inhalational anesthetic agent is considered the agent of choice for day care procedures and the pediatric age group induction.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Sevoflurane is the agent of choice for inhalational induction in pediatric patients and day care procedures due to its non-pungent, sweet smell, minimal airway irritation, and low blood: gas partition coefficient, which allows for rapid induction and emergence.
  • These properties make it ideal for mask induction and quick recovery, both essential in ambulatory and pediatric anesthesia.

Explanation of other options:

Enflurane (Option B): More irritating to the airways; not preferred for induction or day care settings.

Isoflurane (Option C): Pungent odor and airway irritant; poorly tolerated for inhalational induction.

Desflurane (Option D): Although it has a rapid onset and offset, it is very pungent and causes airway irritation, making it unsuitable for induction, especially in children.

Key Takeaways:

  • Sevoflurane is ideal for day care surgery and pediatric induction
  • Offers smooth, rapid induction with minimal airway reactivity
  • Avoid pungent agents like isoflurane and desflurane for inhalational induction

questions.text: Trigger-free anesthesia is a concept that avoids:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Trigger-free anesthesia refers to the avoidance of agents that can precipitate malignant hyperthermia (MH) in susceptible individuals.
  • Volatile inhalational anesthetics (like sevoflurane, desflurane, isoflurane) and succinylcholine are known MH triggers.
  • Therefore, a trigger-free anesthetic technique excludes inhalational agents, instead relying on intravenous drugs, opioids, and non-triggering muscle relaxants.

Explanation of other options:

All non-depolarizing muscle relaxants (Option A): These are safe and not MH triggers.

Nitrous oxide (Option B): Not a trigger for MH, considered safe.

Intravenous induction agent (Option C): Agents like propofol or etomidate are non-triggering.

Key Takeaways:

  • Trigger-free anesthesia avoids inhalational agents and succinylcholine
  • Used for patients with suspected or confirmed MH susceptibility
  • IV-based techniques and non-depolarizing relaxants are safe alternatives

questions.text: Which agent has the lowest blood-gas partition coefficient among the following?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Desflurane has the lowest blood-gas partition coefficient (approximately 0.42) among all commonly used inhalational anesthetics.
  • A lower blood: gas partition coefficient means faster onset and recovery, as the agent remains in the alveoli rather than dissolving in blood.
  • This makes desflurane ideal for cases requiring rapid changes in anesthetic depth and fast emergence.

Explanation of other options:

Isoflurane (Option A): Has a higher blood: gas partition coefficient (~1.4); slower onset and offset.

Sevoflurane (Option B): Faster than isoflurane but still higher (~0.65) than desflurane.

Nitrous oxide (Option D): Although fast-acting, its blood-gas coefficient (~0.47) is higher than desflurane.

Key Takeaways:

  • Desflurane offers the fastest onset and recovery due to its low blood solubility.
  • Low blood: gas coefficient = faster equilibration between alveolar gas and blood
  • Useful in short surgeries or cases needing rapid emergence

choices.text: Dexmedetomidine to smooth out the anesthetic delivery
Continuous propofol infusion as anesthesia maintenance
Half MAC of nitrous oxide to supplement the inhalation agent
1 MAC or higher of sevoflurane as needed for maintenance anesthesia

questions.text: While administering anesthesia for a cervical spine surgery involving intraoperative monitoring of somatosensory-evoked potentials (SSEPs) and motor-evoked potentials (MEPs), which of the following should be avoided in your anesthetic plan alongside long-acting muscle relaxants?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Volatile anesthetics, especially at concentrations of 1 MAC or higher, significantly suppress somatosensory-evoked potentials (SSEPs) and motor-evoked potentials (MEPs) by depressing synaptic transmission in the central nervous system.
  • To preserve the integrity of evoked potential monitoring, it is crucial to use low-dose inhalational agents or switch to total intravenous anesthesia (TIVA)
  • Therefore, using 1 MAC or more of sevoflurane would impair the ability to reliably monitor these signals.

Explanation of other options:

Dexmedetomidine to smooth out the anesthetic delivery (Option A): Does not significantly interfere with evoked potentials; can be used as an adjunct in neuroanesthesia.

Continuous propofol infusion as anesthesia maintenance (Option B): Preferred in SSEP and MEP monitoring; provides stable conditions with minimal interference.

Half MAC of nitrous oxide to supplement the inhalation agent (Option C): At low concentrations, it has a modest effect and may be acceptable in some cases.

Key Takeaways:

  • High-dose volatile agents suppress SSEPs and MEPs, impairing neuromonitoring.
  • Use TIVA (e.g., propofol-based) techniques for better monitoring conditions.s
  • Dexmedetomidine is a safe adjunct; avoid >0.5 MAC inhalational agents.

questions.text: An air bubble is injected into the posterior chamber after retinal surgery (pneumatic retinopexy) to facilitate anatomically correct healing. Before injecting an air bubble into the posterior chamber during pneumatic retinopexy, what is the most appropriate anesthetic management step to prevent complications?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Nitrous oxide diffuses rapidly into air-filled spaces and can cause expansion of intraocular gas bubbles, such as those used in pneumatic retinopexy.
  • This expansion increases intraocular pressure (IOP), potentially leading to optic nerve damage or retinal artery occlusion.
  • Therefore, nitrous oxide must be discontinued before the air bubble is injected to prevent these complications.

Explanation of other options:

Increase the depth of anesthesia (Option A): Does not prevent gas expansion; unrelated to intraocular pressure changes due to nitrous oxide.

Hyperventilation (Option C): Reduces intracranial pressure but does not influence gas expansion in the eye.

Ensure adequate muscle relaxation (Option D): Important for surgical conditions but not related to gas bubble expansion or IOP management.

Key Takeaways:

  • Discontinue nitrous oxide before intraocular gas injection to prevent IOP rise.
  • Nitrous oxide expands air-filled spaces due to its diffusion properties
  • Gas expansion can cause vision-threatening complications

questions.text: A 66-year-old man with severe chronic obstructive airways disease presents for a laparoscopic hernia repair as a day case. Which is the most appropriate anesthetic agent to use in this patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Sevoflurane is the most appropriate inhalational agent for patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) due to its non-irritating nature, bronchodilatory effects, and rapid onset and recovery.
  • It provides smooth induction and maintenance, making it suitable for day-case surgeries.
  • Sevoflurane is well tolerated even in patients with compromised pulmonary function.

Explanation of other options:

Desflurane (Option A): Though it has a rapid onset and offset, it is pungent and can cause airway irritation, coughing, and bronchospasm, undesirable in COPD.

Remifentanil (Option C): An ultrashort-acting opioid, used as an adjunct, but not sufficient alone for general anesthesia in surgical procedures.

Bupivacaine (Option D): A local anesthetic, not used for general anesthesia induction; suitable for regional blocks.

Key Takeaways:

  • Sevoflurane is preferred in COPD due to its bronchodilatory and non-irritant
  • Avoid desflurane in patients with reactive airways
  • Consider a surgical setting (e.g., day case) when choosing agents with rapid recovery

questions.text: Which of the following interacts with CO2 absorbers?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Sevoflurane and desflurane both have known interactions with CO2 absorbers, especially those containing strong bases like sodium hydroxide or potassium hydroxide.
  • Sevoflurane can degrade in the presence of dry CO2 absorbents to produce Compound A, a nephrotoxic vinyl ether.
  • Desflurane can react to form carbon monoxide, particularly with desiccated absorbents, posing a risk of carboxyhemoglobinemia.
  • These reactions are more pronounced with dry absorbents and elevated temperatures.

Explanation of other options:

Isoflurane (Option C): Less likely to interact significantly; minimal compound formation reported.

Key Takeaways:

  • Sevoflurane forms Compound A; desflurane may produce carbon monoxide
  • Interaction is more with dry CO2 absorbers containing strong bases
  • Avoid desiccated absorbents in vaporizer circuits with these agents
